At 1627 hours on January 8, 2023 Officer Barnes received a call at 411 Washington Street for a larceny report.  The 911 Call came in at 1423 hours and was held for approximately 90  minutes.  The call was coded as a priority 7 call.  

Officer Barnes responded to the 90 minute old, priority 7 call with his emergency lights activated and proceeded to drive through two red lights without stopping or slowing down.  At roll call, 20 minutes prior to this call Barnes received training in rule 302.  

Barnes disregarded the training he received in the police academy and the roll call training he received immediately before going to this call.  Barnes put the public and himself in harm's way with his unsafe driving in addition to creating liability for the department.  

PO Barnes violated rule 302 sec. 4.1 (Emergency Driving)

Refer to Sergeant Crossen and Lieutenant Walsh's Form 26's as well as the preserved FLIR Video in Sergeant Crossen's possession.  

It should be noted that On March 23, 2023 Officer Barnes was found at fault for rear ending a motor vehicle (I232022447).

On February 2, 2023 Officer Barnes violated rules 309 sec. 4 (Evidence and Found Property) and rule 102 sec. 4 (Neglect of Duty) when he discarded evidence/personal property in the dumpster.  Additionally, he failed to document it in his incident report.  Again, Officer Barnes opened himself and the department up to liability.  

Refer to Lieutenant Walsh's Form 26.  

On February 8, 2023 Officer Barnes violated rule 309 sec. 4 (Evidence and Found Property) when he again discarded evidence in the dumpster. 

Refer to Lieutenant Walsh's Form 26.
  
On February 12, 2023 Officer Barnes violated rule 102 sec 4 (Neglect of Duty/Judgement) when he delayed and was hesitant putting out a broadcast to fellow officers pertaining to a BOLO for a person with a gun.  Officer Barnes stated that he did not want to get involved in making the broadcast for the suspects location which created an officer safety issue.  

Sergeant Crossen is in possession of FLIR camera footage of the incident. 

On February 26, 2023 Officer Barnes violated rule 102 sec. 4 (Neglect of Duty) when he responded to a motor vehicle accident where a vehicle crashed into several cars rendering it disabled and blocking the opposite lane of traffic on a congested street in the North End and failed to remain on scene to assist with traffic and maintain scene safety until the vehicle was towed.  Officer Barnes had to be called back to the scene to secure the scene by Patrol Supervisor Sergeant Crossen. 

Refer to Sergeant Crossen's Form 26. 

On March 4, 2023 Officer Barnes Violated rule 102 sec 4 (Neglect of Duty) (2 counts) when he responded to a call for a motor vehicle accident with a drunk driver.  Officer Barnes misceled the call with a 15P and left the scene.  A few hours later another call came in reporting the vehicle was still disabled, blocking the road, that the vehicle was missing a tire, had struck several cars and that the operator was unresponsive in the car and there was a large quantity of marijuana inside the vehicle.  Officer Barnes responded back to the scene and again miceled the call never addressing the mva with multiple vehicles, the potentially intoxicated driver or the large amount of marijuana in the vehicle as reported by the Boston Fire Department.  

Refer to Sergeant McClay's Form 26

On May 7th Officer Barnes violated rules 102 sec. 9 (Respectful Treatment) and 102 sec. 8 (Directives and Orders) when he disproportionately responded to a disagreement (over officer Barnes actions/inaction on scene with a hostile crowd while officers were attempting to gain control of them-body camera preserved) with Officer Entwistle in the guardroom and failed to follow an order/directive from Captain McCormick to stand down.    

Refer to Captain McCormick's Form 26 along with the Form 26's of the Officers present during the incident. 

The number, type and frequency of rule violations accumulated is such a short period of time by a probationary officer raises serious concerns for this captain.

At approximately 11:30am, Wednesday, 6/14/2023, the Area A-1 Investigative Commander, Lieutenant Detective Stanley Demesmin, made observations of Detective Sean Deery (ID #11597) that led him to believe that Detective Deery was intoxicated while on duty.

Lieutenant Detective Demesmin reported that Detective Deery was in the bathroom an inordinate number of times. He further reported that he made observations of Detective Deery being unsteady on his feet, having glossy eyes and made note of an odor of alcohol emanating from Detective Deery. Captain Shawm Martin observed Detective Deery to have glossy eyes, walking both slowly and deliberately, and speaking slowly. Captain Martin immediately recognized that Detective Deery was not acting in his normal capacity and concurred with Lieutenant Demesmins assessment that Detective Deery was intoxicated while on duty. Lieutenant Thomas Leahy was also present with Captain Martin and Lieutenant Detective Demesmin as they made their observations. 

Detective Deerys service weapon was taken into custody, and he was relieved of duty pending further investigative steps. The determination was made that Detective Deery was unfit to operate a motor vehicle safely and was transported home by Detective David Juba. A search of Detective Deerys workspace yielded four empty bottles of wine which were photographed and collected. Detective Deery refused several of the A-1 Commanders request to submit to alcohol testing. 

Administrative reports to be completed and forwarded to the Bureau of Investigative Services.
Disciplines: Suspension: 1-5 days, Other (Seek counseling for alcohol abuse.)

She stated this has been on-going issue with Detective Deery for 2 months with the ME's Office attempting to reach Detective Derry in order to be able to bury the unclaimed person from the sudden death.  Sergeant Detective Cellucci spoke with Colleen Alvarez, and she forwarded a copy of emails, an exhaustion letter and the emails sent to Detective Derry, as well as she has documentation of phone calls made to him that were not answered.  She stated she felt his response was an attack on the ME's Office, unprofessional, disrespectful and are now included in work product related to the unclaimed person.

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Policy 900: Temporary Custody of Adults:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

f. Section 900.8: Cells which states the following:
A thorough inspection of a cell shall be conducted by the supervisor in charge of booking (e.g. the Officer-in-Charge or Desk Sergeant) before placing an individual into the cell to ensure there are no weapons or contraband and that the cell is clean and sanitary.

1. Policy 321: Standards of Conduct:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:
a. Section 321.6.8: Efficiency which states the following:
a. Neglect of duty.
b. Unsatisfactory work performance including but not limited to failure, incompetence, inefficiency, or delay in performing and/or carrying out proper orders, work assignments, or the instructions of supervisors without a reasonable and bona fide excuse.

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Policy 900: Temporary Custody of Adults:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

d. Section 900.4: Initiating Temporary Custody which states the following:
The officer responsible for an individual in temporary custody should evaluate the person for any apparent chronic illness, disability, vermin infestation, possible communicable disease, or any other potential risk to the health or safety of the individual or others. The officer shall specifically ask if the individual is contemplating suicide and evaluate him/her for obvious signs or indications of suicidal intent (G.L. c. 40,  36A).

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Procedure 901: Booking Procedure:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

a.	Section 901.2.1 Arrival at Station which states the following:

Use of Telephone:
1.	The detainee will be informed orally by the booking officer that he/she has the right to use the telephone, and that he/she will be allowed to exercise this right upon completion of the booking process, or within one hour of arrival at the station, whichever first occurs.

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Procedure 901: Booking Procedure:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

b. Section 901.2.6 Fingerprinting and Photographing which states the following:

All persons arrested by this department shall be fingerprinted and photographed. Facial and side profile photographs shall be taken as well as photographs of all tattoos and any distinctive scars or marks. Prisoners shall not be required to remove clothing in order to be photographed. The booking officer will review the fingerprint print-out report prior to releasing or transferring the prisoner to confirm the prisoners identity.

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Procedure 901: Booking Procedure:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

c. Section 901.2.8 Detainees Rights which states the following:

During the booking process, the Booking Officer shall:
a. Inform the detainee of his/her rights, including the right to consult with an attorney, by reading the Miranda Warning from the printed card on the booking room wall or the booking sheet.
b. Inform the detainee again of his/her right to the use of the telephone. [S]he shall be allowed to exercise his/her right in order to contact family or friends, to arrange for bail, or to contact an attorney at the completion of the booking process.

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Procedure 901: Booking Procedure:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

d. Section 901.2.9 Placement in a Cell which states the following:

Prior to placing a detainee in a cell within the holding facility, the booking officer shall conduct a security search of the cell, including a search for weapons and contraband.

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
Procedure 901: Booking Procedure:

e. Section 901.2.10 Medical Screening and Treatment Procedures which states the following:

The prisoner shall, upon arrival at the station and before transfer to another facility, be received and screened by the Booking Officer. This screening shall consist a brief inquiry into:
a. The current health of the detainee;
b. Any medications being taken;
c. Behavioral observations, including consciousness and mental status; and
d. A notation of any obvious body deformities, trauma markings, bruises, lesions, jaundice, ease of movement, etc. If any injuries do exist, the booking officer shall inquire as to whether these injuries were sustained during or prior to the arrest.
e. An inquiry if the detainee requires medical assistance.
All observations shall be noted in the IMC booking section.
Medical treatment shall be arranged for any detainee in need of medical treatment

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
4. Procedure 901: Data Collection Procedure:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

a. Section 902.3 Data Collection Procedures which states the following:
The collection of the below listed data fields is mandatory for compliance with 501 CMR 18.00. The following procedures are intended to supplement current booking practices; and are not meant to replace current practices for data collection. These procedures apply to an arrest or summons based upon a new criminal offense or a warrant arrest in a criminal case. Members of the Tewksbury Police Department shall adhere to the following procedures:
A. Arrest Booking:
1. Self-Reported Data: Upon arrest of an offender for a new offense or on a warrant in a criminal case, the following information shall be self-reported by the offender and entered appropriately into the Records Management System. An offender's refusal to answer a question must be recorded as "information not provided based upon unwillingness to answer". The Officer must not attempt to provide their own responses to offender's self-reported data. Self-reported data is as follows:
a. Name
b. Date of birth
c. Aliases
d. Race
e. Ethnicity
f. Gender Identity
g. Assigned Sex
h. Pronouns
i. Whether the Offender is the Primary Caretaker of a Child
j. Offender's address at time of arrest
2. Fingerprint data:
a. All offenders arrested for a felony or misdemeanor shall be fingerprinted regardless of whether the offender is known to the Law Enforcement Agency and has been previously fingerprinted by that same Agency.
b. The Officer is required to fingerprint the offender in accordance with 501 CMR 18.00, 803 CMR 7.08, and MSP SIS Policies and Procedures to obtain a State Identification Number (SID)

Allegation_Subtype: Improper processing of prisoners or property
Allegation_Details:
5. Procedure 901: Detaining Prisoners Procedure:
Lieutenant Williams violated the following sections:

a. Section 903.2.3 Prisoner Monitoring which states the following:
Any video monitors and audio listening devices installed in the cell block areas shall be turned on whenever a person is placed into one of the cells in the holding facility and shall be left on as long as anyone is being detained there. In the event that the audio system is inoperative or non-operational, the detainee shall be within audible range of the duty desk without electronic assistance.
a. It is the responsibility of the Officer-in-Charge/Desk Sergeant to ensure the proper monitoring of all persons held in the holding facility.

Allegation_Details: Hopkinton Police Rules and Regulations 10.0: Attention to Duty "Officers are expected to be constantly alert and vigilant in the performance of their duties and to respond prudently but decisively when police action is required or expected. Every employee of the department who has occasion to handle any complaint, assistance call, arrest or other duty with business-like dispatch and courtesy and without any unnecessary loss of time. Employees shall furnish information and render aid to all persons with due courtesy whenever such request is consistent with their duty. Employees shall not withhold information on criminal activity from the department or other authorized personnel where there is a duty to disclose some information.
Disciplines: Termination or similar (Terminated after hearing on Feb 8, 2024.)
